scenes.title: Rituals against uncertainty
scenes.main_point: Rituals provide structure when life feels uncertain.
scenes.scene_summary: I realized rituals mattered most when uncertainty made everything feel unsteady.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person at a small desk at home, arranging a simple daily ritual (notebook and cup) into a neat routine.
The room feels unsteady with scattered items around, while the ritual area is orderly, implying uncertainty held in check.

scenes.title: Religion to secular life
scenes.main_point: Religion historically provided structure; secularization reduced reliance on it.
scenes.scene_summary: Religion once gave people structure, then secularization made society rely on it less.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
In an Enlightenment-era European town square, townspeople shift from gathering around a church for guidance to consulting a civic notice board.
The church stands in the background as secular institutions take focus, implying a calmer, more self-directed mood.

scenes.title: Problems are inevitable
scenes.main_point: Change brings problems, and problems can be useful and meaningful.
scenes.scene_summary: I accepted that change brings problems, and problems keep our minds engaged.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person sits at a simple desk, looking at a page labeled “Change” with a small list of “Problems,” hands relaxed in gratitude.
Quiet room setting; expression thoughtful, finding meaning in the problems.

scenes.title: Morning reading ritual
scenes.main_point: A focused, phone-free hour of reading starts the day.
scenes.scene_summary: I started each day with one focused hour of reading—no phone, just a book.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person sits in bed or at a small bedside chair, reading a Kindle or physical book for an hour.
A phone is set aside and untouched on the nightstand, emphasizing a calm morning ritual.

scenes.title: Stoicism as balance
scenes.main_point: Stoicism is about balance, not suppressing emotions.
scenes.scene_summary: Stoicism aimed for balance, not emotionless suppression like many people assumed.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
Ryan Holiday stands in a simple study beside a copy of “Ego is the Enemy,” calmly holding one hand over his heart and the other open, illustrating stoicism as emotional balance rather than suppression.

scenes.title: To be vs to do
scenes.main_point: Process beats outcome-driven visualization; focus on what to do now.
scenes.scene_summary: Outcome-driven visualization missed the daily grind, so I focused on doing now.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person at a desk with a vision board labeled “Outcome” pushed aside, writing a simple to-do list labeled “Process” while a small note shows a Derek Sivers quote.
Home workspace; focused, determined.

scenes.title: Don’t chase passion
scenes.main_point: “Find your passion” can feed ego; consistent work matters more.
scenes.scene_summary: Chasing passion fed ego, so I chose steady work over grand quests.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A single person at a desk closes a book labeled “Passion” and opens a notebook labeled “Steady Work,” with “Ego” scribbled and crossed out.
On the desk lie two books titled “Cal Newport” and “Anna Lembke,” in a quiet study; the person looks resolved.

scenes.title: Endurance sports consistency
scenes.main_point: Dispassionate consistency in running inspired more than hype or fandom.
scenes.scene_summary: I wasn’t passionate about running, but consistency in training kept moving me forward.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A lone runner trains steadily on a simple track, focused and calm, not hyped.
A small note or sign nearby references “Kipchoge,” emphasizing consistency in endurance running.

scenes.title: Make the team look good
scenes.main_point: Early career trust comes from reliable grunt work and delivery.
scenes.scene_summary: I built trust by doing disliked tasks well and delivering more than I talked.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
An intern and a small team at an office workspace; the intern quietly completes a stack of disliked grunt-work tasks and hands the finished results to teammates.
The team looks relieved and trusting.

scenes.title: Get out of your head
scenes.main_point: Perfectionism and spotlight effect come from ego; most people aren’t watching.
scenes.scene_summary: I dropped perfectionist fantasies and remembered most people stayed focused on themselves.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A person stands in a room with vision boards and a “perfect plan” pinned up, then lowers their shoulders and steps back from the wall.
Around them, other people in the same space stay focused on their own tasks, not looking over; the person looks relieved.

scenes.title: Restraint through rejection
scenes.main_point: Rejection and silence sting; restraint keeps ego from taking over.
scenes.scene_summary: Rejections and ignored emails hurt, so I practiced restraint instead of lashing out.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
An immigrant job seeker sits at a small desk, staring at a laptop showing an interview rejection and unanswered cold emails.
They clench a fist in anger, then relax their hand, practicing restraint in the quiet room.

scenes.title: Infinite game and leadership
scenes.main_point: Stay a student, focus on actions, avoid entitlement, and lead with credit and responsibility.
scenes.scene_summary: I played the infinite game: act daily, reject entitlement, credit the team, own failures.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A leader stands at a whiteboard labeled “No finish line,” facing a small team in a meeting room.
They point to a list of daily actions and feedback notes, while writing “Credit team” and “Take blame,” with a calm, accountable expression.
